Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} + v\\cdot\\nabla u = 0\\), where \\(u(t,x)\\) represents the state of the system and \\(v\\) is a constant velocity vector. The impact of a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) applied to the initial condition \\(u_0(x)\\) is studied to determine its effect over time.

If the Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}(u_0)\\) is implemented on the initial condition \\(u_0(x)\\), then the system evolves according to the given PDE without further intervention. Will the state \\(u(T,x)\\) at time T be the same as if the untransformed \\(u_0(x)\\) was evolved to time T?
Explanation: Applying the Fourier transform as an initial condition alters the spatial frequency components of \\(u_0(x)\\), and hence the derived solution \\(u(T, x)\\) will differ significantly. The evolution as per the PDE respects these initial frequencies, therefore leading to a distinct state at time T.
